I like the addition of the support, couple of things below.  I'm not super well versed in clustered mysql so it would be great to get some other db experts to look at this.

I also suspect we need to figure out how to bring the rest of the committers (like myself) up to speed on the added types here and what needs to be done to deal with clustered mysql.

I guess I'd like to see some sort of mysql-cluster unit tests to check that sort of thing; also shouldn't there be some sort of unit tests for what you've added here?"}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2017-11-17 09:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

While I'm fine with the code, I agree with John here. It's not obvious when table needs some "shrinking" to fit into MySQL Cluster limits. It would be good to have unit tests that will check that to make sure we won't break the support later on.

Also some developer documentation on what the limits are and how to work around them would be very helpful.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2017-11-17 14:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> I like the addition of the support, couple of things below.  I'm
 > not super well versed in clustered mysql so it would be great to
 > get some other db experts to look at this.
 > 
 > I also suspect we need to figure out how to bring the rest of the
 > committers (like myself) up to speed on the added types here and
 > what needs to be done to deal with clustered mysql.
 > 
 > I guess I'd like to see some sort of mysql-cluster unit tests to
 > check that sort of thing; also shouldn't there be some sort of unit
 > tests for what you've added here?

hi -

so i would note that the way I've helped Octave to make this work is that oslo.db selects out these alternate NDB-specific type declarations, only when the NDB storage engine is enabled.   If the ndb flag isn't turned on, the datatypes emitted by the 085_cinder_init.py migration should not change at all.

Another part of the arrangement w/ Octave / Oracle is that they are agreeing to maintain this "NDB-ness" of the openstack applications they are modifying.  Because yes all of us raised concerns that all these new conditionals are being put in.    What you see here is our efforts to reduce as much verbosity in downstream (of oslo.db) projects as possible.

the way migration unit tests work now across openstack is that they are actually functional tests and run the migrations againast an actual database, and use fixtures like  oslo.db MySQLOpportunisticFixture to run the migrations on a real MySQL / MariaDB database.  So in this case, Oracle should be providing an NDB_enabled environment to plug into openstack's CI.    Other than that, the datatype objects here themselves are tested that they do the right thing at the unit level in oslo.db.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2017-11-17 15:49:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Okay, if there's a test plan, that's fine. Still a bit of the developer oriented documentation on how this works would be desired."}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2017-12-12 14:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2017-12-12 17:00:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> so i would note that the way I've helped Octave to make this work is > that oslo.db selects out these alternate NDB-specific type 
> declarations, only when the NDB storage engine is enabled.   If the > ndb flag isn't turned on, the datatypes emitted by the 
> 085_cinder_init.py migration should not change at all.

So is there a path to upgrade to MySQL Cluster after this migration?  What does that process look like?  At the very least this should have some release note and some info in the docs ref.

> Another part of the arrangement w/ Octave / Oracle is that they are > agreeing to maintain this "NDB-ness" of the openstack applications 
> they are modifying.  
What does that mean?  maintain it where, for who?  I'm sorry I don't understand, is this a commitment saying you or someone from your team that is knowledgeable will now be available to review every Cinder change that touches the DB schema etc?

> Because yes all of us raised concerns that all these new 
> conditionals are being put in.    
Maybe that's and indication that we need to think of a good way to document this very fully and educate folks (myself included)?

> What you see here is our efforts 
> to reduce as much verbosity in downstream (of oslo.db) projects as 
> possible.
I certainly appreciate that, and that's awesome.  On the other hand, hiding too much upstream in oslo.db does have it's down sides as well.

So... I'm still not a great resource for this review, note the questions above.  I'd be more neutral on this if there were some docs added and some sort of info about how to upgrade etc.



the way migration unit tests work now across openstack is that they are actually functional tests and run the migrations againast an actual database, and use fixtures like  oslo.db MySQLOpportunisticFixture to run the migrations on a real MySQL / MariaDB database.  So in this case, Oracle should be providing an NDB_enabled environment to plug into openstack's CI.    Other than that, the datatype objects here themselves are tested that they do the right thing at the unit level in oslo.db.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2017-12-18 19:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-2

One other thought, shouldn't the spec be finalized and approved before the implementation?

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-28 21:18:54.000000000', 'message': 'Enable MySQL Cluster Support for Cinder

Implements minor fixes to the SQL Alchemy scripts in Cinder to support the
MySQL Cluster DB. This includes the usage of the boolean mysql_enable_ndb
setting from oslo.db from bug 1564110. This allows operators to select from
MySQL (InnoDB) or MySQL Cluster (NDB) as the storage engine backend.
Additionally, this fixes the models.py to support this enhancement.

Change-Id: Id717406bdb34bec20c57ae9ae0e50607738fb91d
Depends-On: I7f9c830073bf9a30abce0aa4bb55b5c9cf661afe

commit_message:
Enable MySQL Cluster Support for Cinder

Implements minor fixes to the SQL Alchemy scripts in Cinder
to support the MySQL Cluster DB. This includes the usage of
the boolean mysql_enable_ndb setting from oslo.db from bug
1564110. This allows operators to select from MySQL (InnoDB)
MySQL Cluster (NDB) as the storage engine backend.
Additionally, this fixes the models.py to support this
enhancement.

Change-Id: Id717406bdb34bec20c57ae9ae0e50607738fb91d
Depends-On: I7f9c830073bf9a30abce0aa4bb55b5c9cf661afe
Implements: blueprint mysql-cluster-support
Closes-Bug: 1707288

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-11 11:56:05.000000000', 'message': "Ensure redis_tls_proxy starts after all redis instances

When converting a HA control plane to TLS-e, 1) the bootstrap node
tells pacemaker to restart all redis instances to take into
account the new TLS-e config; 2) a new container redis_tls_proxy
is started on every controller to encapsulate redis traffic in TLS
tunnels. This happens during step 2.

Redis servers have to be restarted everywhere for redis_tls_proxy
to be able to start tunnels properly. Since we can't guarantee that
across several nodes during the same step, tweak the startup of
redis_tls_proxy instead; make sure to only create the tunnels once
the targeted host:port can be bound (i.e. redis was restarted).

Change-Id: I70560f80775dacddd82262e8079c13f86b0eb0e6
Closes-Bug: #1883096

commit_message:
Ensure redis_tls_proxy starts after all redis instances

When converting a HA control plane to TLS-e, 1) the bootstrap node
tells pacemaker to restart all redis instances to take into
account the new TLS-e config; 2) a new container redis_tls_proxy
is started on every controller to encapsulate redis traffic in TLS
tunnels. This happens during step 2.

Redis servers have to be restarted everywhere for redis_tls_proxy
to be able to start tunnels properly. Since we can't guarantee that
across several nodes during the same step, tweak the startup of
redis_tls_proxy instead; make sure to only create the tunnels once
the targeted host:port can be bound (i.e. redis was restarted).

Change-Id: I70560f80775dacddd82262e8079c13f86b0eb0e6
Closes-Bug: #1883096

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-21 03:55:52.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Make glance-api able to do async tasks in WSGI mode

This is the result of me trying to investigate how infeasible it is to
actually properly support the async task infrastructure under uwsgi. I
was pretty surprised to find that it seems not very hard. I'm sure there
are some gotchas still, but at the very least, I can do image imports
in uwsgi mode with this with some hand testing.

This needs unit tests and probaly some more surveying of things like
the scrubber (I dunno what that is) to see if it should be converted.
That said, this seems to be more trivial than I thought and makes me
reconsider the work we've done recently to make standalone glance-api
the preferred mechanism.

Anyway, I'm putting this up to get some test runs and for discussion,
and will work on the remaining bits.

Change-Id: Ie15028b75fb8518ec2b0c0c0386d21782166f759

'}, {'created': '2020-07-23 17:10:25.000000000', 'message': 'Make glance-api able to do async tasks in WSGI mode

This teaches glance-api how to do async threading things when it is
running in pure-WSGI mode. In order to do that, a refactoring of things
that currently depend on eventlet is required.

It adds a [wsgi]/task_pool_threads configuration knob, which is used
in the case of pure-WSGI and native threads to constrain the number
of threads in that pool (and thus the task parallelism). This will
allow tuning by the operator, but also lets us default that to just
a single thread in the backport of these fixes so that we can avoid
introducing a new larger footprint in the backport unexpectedly.

Partial-Bug: #1888713
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742047/
Change-Id: Ie15028b75fb8518ec2b0c0c0386d21782166f759
'}, {'created': '2020-07-24 17:49:58.000000000', 'message': 'Make glance-api able to do async tasks in WSGI mode

This teaches glance-api how to do async threading things when it is
running in pure-WSGI mode. In order to do that, a refactoring of things
that currently depend on eventlet is required.

in the case of pure-WSGI and native threads to constrain the number

commit_message:
Make glance-api able to do async tasks in WSGI mode

This teaches glance-api how to do async threading things when it is
running in pure-WSGI mode. In order to do that, a refactoring of things
that currently depend on eventlet is required.

It adds a [wsgi]/task_pool_threads configuration knob, which is used
in the case of pure-WSGI and native threads to constrain the number
of threads in that pool (and thus the task parallelism). This will
allow tuning by the operator, but also lets us default that to just
a single thread in the backport of these fixes so that we can avoid
introducing a new larger footprint in the backport unexpectedly.

Partial-Bug: #1888713
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742047/
Change-Id: Ie15028b75fb8518ec2b0c0c0386d21782166f759

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-13 09:44:01.000000000', 'message': "Load br_netfilter module in nova-cell role

The nova-cell role sets the following sysctls on compute hosts, which
require the br_netfilter kernel module to be loaded:

    net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables
    net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-ip6tables

If it is not loaded, then we see the following errors:

    Failed to reload sysctl:
    sysctl: cannot stat /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-iptables: No such file or directory
    sysctl: cannot stat /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-ip6tables: No such file or directory

Loading the br_netfilter module resolves this issue.

Typically we do not see this since installing Docker and configuring it
to manage iptables rules causes the br_netfilter module to be loaded.
There are good reasons [1] to disable Docker's iptables management
however, in which case we are likely to hit this issue.

This change loads the br_netfilter module in the nova-cell role for
compute hosts.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1849275

Co-Authored-By: Dincer Celik <hello@dincercelik.com>

Closes-Bug: #1886796

Change-Id: Id52668ba8dab460ad4c33fad430fc8611e70825e
(cherry picked from commit 2f91be9f391f3aa5ef80248ca821b3f34e73bf24)

commit_message:
Load br_netfilter module in nova-cell role

The nova-cell role sets the following sysctls on compute hosts, which
require the br_netfilter kernel module to be loaded:

    net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables
    net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-ip6tables

If it is not loaded, then we see the following errors:

    Failed to reload sysctl:
    sysctl: cannot stat /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-iptables: No such file or directory
    sysctl: cannot stat /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-ip6tables: No such file or directory

Loading the br_netfilter module resolves this issue.

Typically we do not see this since installing Docker and configuring it
to manage iptables rules causes the br_netfilter module to be loaded.
There are good reasons [1] to disable Docker's iptables management
however, in which case we are likely to hit this issue.

This change loads the br_netfilter module in the nova-cell role for
compute hosts.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1849275

Co-Authored-By: Dincer Celik <hello@dincercelik.com>

Closes-Bug: #1886796

Change-Id: Id52668ba8dab460ad4c33fad430fc8611e70825e
(cherry picked from commit 2f91be9f391f3aa5ef80248ca821b3f34e73bf24)

commit_message:
Smarter Nova service management

This patch introduces a new NovaServiceManager class. This class uses
Nova's os-services API to make sure the service is actually up or
down, instead of dumbly sleep()ing.

Because the restart() method now calls stop and start in sequence, the
[whitebox-nova-compute]/restart_command config option is no longer
necessary, and has been removed. In its place, a new
[whitebox-nova-compute]/start_command option is needed.

Change-Id: I7b0c3635298b68981d9c460769a4d4ac9805357a

commit_message:
Trivial: use condition instead of try/except

When getting a service's config, stop using try/except to tell if the
conf exists, and instead use a cleaner `if hasattr`.

Change-Id: Ib98ff29a38dfaaeff144958c3e0ac3c141429ba9

commit_message:
Ensure distro packages are present for utility wheel build

The python packages installed into the utility container require
gcc and the python development packages to be present in order to
build the wheels.

Change-Id: I3a99bfb3fec9f47d407ec6f6555094836aedb785
(cherry picked from commit abf978005752c75032f362f3bd1eaa4f70155ad4)
